prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 spectral line: SiO v=0 (2-1): CND mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic observation of Circumnuclear Ring in the SiO v=0 (2-1) line to investigate massive star formation in the Galactic Center. This will be combined with observations of other transitions to identify protostellar outflow candidates in the molecular ring.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In Band 3, we will observe the SiO v=0 (2-1) transition at 86.847 GHz using 27 Nyquist-sampled fields.

Each 72" field will be observed down to an rms noise level of 10 mJy in a 1 km/s channel. We will also use an additional baseband centered on a methanol transition at 84.52117 GHz. The third baseband will observe two methanol lines at 96.73936, 96.7555 GHz and the fourth baseband will observe a methanol line at 99.7309 GHz. A total of 1.50 hour -- including calibrations -- will be required to satisfy this science goal. In Band 3, all lines will be observed at sub-km/s spectral resolution and total bandwidth of at least 700 km/s.

In order to detect and measure SiO emission in the entire molecular ring. we are proposing a mosaic over 2.5' x 2.5 area, centered on Sgr A* with a far better sensitivity and coverage than on the small, seven-field mosaic (5-4) of the Cycle 1 ALMA SVO. We will obtain mosaic observations in the SiO v=0 (2-1) line and will scale the arrays to obtain a synthesized beamsize of 0.4" in the SiO v=0 (5-4) in Band 6. The CND is clumpy with clump sizes up to about few arcseconds. Because we want to match this lowest frequency to the other higher frequency SiO transitions, this goal requires nearly the resolution limit at this frequency of 0.4".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 spectral line: SiO v=0 (5-4): CND mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic observation of Circumnuclear Ring in the SiO v=0 (5-4) line to investigate massive star formation in the Galactic Center. This will be combined with observations of other transitions to identify protostellar outflow candidates in the molecular ring.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Averaging across the line channels in Band 6 will also provide a sensitive continuum measurement with rms noise levels of about 0.4 mJy.
In order to detect and measure SiO emission in the entire molecular ring. In order to achieve 15 mJy rms in a 1 km/s channel for the line observations, it will require 2.02 hours.

We are proposing a mosaic over 2.5' x 2.5 area, centered on Sgr A*. We will obtain mosaic observations in the SiO v=0 (5-4) line and will scale the array to that of the SiO v=0 (2-1) to obtain a synthesized beamsize of 0.4" in both bands. We use one baseband to observe the SiO v=0 (5-4) line at 217.1050 GHz with a requested synthesized beamsize of 0.4 arcseconds to match the other mosaic observation, requiring 137 pointings to cover the 2.5 arcminute field of view. In another baseband, we will observe three H2CO transitions at 218 GHz. A third baseband will be used to observe CO v=0 (2-1) at 230.538 GHz. We will use a forth baseband to observe the continuum using 2 GHz of bandwidth.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 spectral line: SiO v=0 (5-4): High res on sources 1 & 11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Single pointing observation of sources 1 & 11 in the SiO v=0 (5-4) line to investigate massive star formation in the Galactic Center for these two sources at the highest resolution.
Note, there are two source: Source 1 and Source 11 from 2013 ApJ paper.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe a single field centered on Sgr A* which includes two remarkable SiO sources 1 and 11 that appear to be associated with IR excess sources with SEDs similar to YSOs.

We will use the same back-end setup as the Band 6 mosaic. This will require 59.39 minutes total time, including calibration and overhead. For Band 6, all lines will be observed with at least 1.3 km/s spectral resolution and 640 km/s total coverage.
We request an additional science goal observing SiO in Band 6 to observe two SiO sources at the highest spatial resolution ~0.189".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 spectral line: SiO v=0 (7-6): Ring source targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Single pointing observations in SiO v=0 (7-6) line at the positions of previously detected SiO (5-4) sources to investigate massive star formation in the Galactic Center.
Note, there are 9 pointings targeting several sources from 2013 ApJ paper.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Averaging across the line channels in Band 7 will also provide a sensitive continuum measurement with rms noise levels of about 0.2 mJy.

This high frequency line is weaker that lower frequency transitions in a single component model. However, it allows us to search for a hot dense core. In order to achieve 10 mJy rms noise in a 1 km/s band we will require a 1.06 hours of total time, including calibration and overhead. In another baseband we will observe H2CO 4(1,3)-3(1,2) at 300.836635 GHz. We will use the third baseband to observe DCN v=0, J=4-3 at 289.64491 GHz and three transitions of H2CO at 290 GHz. The fourth baseband will observe H2CO 4(2,2)-3(2,1) at 291.94807 GHz.
We will observe targeted observations of 9 sources at SiO v=0 (7-6) 303.927 GHz in the ring where there is previously-detected strong SiO (2-1) and (5-4) emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent ALMA, CARMA, SMA, VLA & GBT observations of the Galactic center show highly excited SiO (5-4) and (2-1) line emission as well as methanol and water masers within 2 arcmin of the 4 million solar mass black hole Sgr A*. These lines suggest on-going star formation. We aim to test that this emission is tracing star formation between 0.2 & 6 pc from Sgr A* in the orbiting molecular ring and its interior. This will be achieved by resolving the SiO (5-4), (7-6) & (2-1) line emission from protostellar outflow candidates and demonstrating the kinematics and morphology of jet driven outflows. In addition, we will search for continuum sources at the center of protostellar outflow candidates to determine whether they have the dust continua characteristic of embedded high-mass protostars. Our proposed ALMA study of the molecular ring and its interior will establish or exclude the star formation hypothesis and will be able to characterize properties of molecular gas within the inner 6pc of Sgr A*.
